sentences.sentence: Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault said it would be a criminal offence(https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/saskatchewan-running-coal-power-later-than-2030-would-be-illegal-guilbeault) if Premier Scott Moe keeps Saskatchewan's three coal power plants, which produce(https://www.saskpower.com/our-power-future/our-electricity/electrical-system/balancing-supply-options) around a quarter of the province's electricity, open past 2030.Canadians are being told by Ottawa(https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2020/11/the-government-of-canada-is-leading-by-example-on-combatting-climate-change.html) and the international community(https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/unep-environment-canada-green-tech-1.3422440) that in order to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions, we must lead by example and cut our meagre 1.5 per cent share of global emissions to zero, ignoring Canadians' well-being, standards of living and energy security.

Yet big emitters like China, India and Germany are not following our lead.Moving the goalposts from 2050, one part of Ottawa's net-zero plan is to implement clean electricity regulations (CER) to achieve a "net-zero" electrical grid by 2035, a plan that builds on Ottawa's 2018 coal power regulations.

Those regulations specify the closure of coal power plants by 2029.Pre-empting the recently announced Canada electricity advisory council before it has even met, Guilbeault has now faced off with Premier Moe, who contends that Ottawa's unilateral decision to achieve net-zero emissions in power production by 2035 is unrealistic, even unachievable, without causing massive disruption.

(https://www.theepochtimes.com/saskatchewan-premier-says-net-zero-plan-by-2035-unrealistic_5273564.html?utm_source=BN_article_paid&;src_src=BN_article_paid&;utm_campaign=breaking-2023-05-17-ca&;src_cmp=breaking-2023-05-17-ca&;utm_medium=email&;est=%5bEMAIL_SECURE_LINK%5d&;utm_term=news4&;utm_content=4C:\Users\Ron%20%20Wallace\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\INetCache\Content.Outlook\PFVLJC3D\Saskatchewan%20Premier%20Says%20Net%20Zero%20Plan%20by%202035%20%E2%80%98Unrealistic%E2%80%99%20(theepochtimes.com)Saskatchewan%20Premier%20Says%20Net%20Zero%20Plan%20by%202035%20%E2%80%98Unrealistic%E2%80%99%20(theepochtimes.com) )"We will not attempt the impossible when it comes to power production in our province," said Moe.

Instead, the premier sensibly proposed to fulfill the original net-zero target by 2050.Guilbeault immediately countered(https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/saskatchewan-plan-to-run-coal-power-plants-beyond-2030-would-be-illegal-guilbeault-says) the Saskatchewan proposal with a threat: "We've regulated the ban on coal through CEPA (the Canadian Environmental Protection Act), which is a criminal tool that the federal government has... so not complying with this regulation would be a violation of Canada's Criminal Code.

"Moe replied(https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/sask-moe-coal-2030-1.6848276), "When individuals in this province, or any other province, they flick their lights on or their furnace fan kicks in that's deemed illegal and cause for someone to go to jail, come get me.... We're standing up for an affordable reliable power supply here in Saskatchewan.
None of those are provided by the federal net-zero plan."
Indeed.The proposed federal clean electricity regulations are a "one-size-fits-all" policy in an area of clear provincial jurisdiction that is rapidly evolving into a threat to national unity.

Less than eight per cent of Canada's overall emissions come from coal power, yet the CER would effectively criminalize reliable, affordable energy based on coal.Canadians are being told(https://decisions.scc-csc.ca/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/18781/index.do) that emissions and climate change are a global problem that requires global co-operation.
So, are other countries following our lead by shutting coal power plants and keeping coal in the ground?
"The world's first-, third- and seventh-largest emitters (China, India and Germany, respectively) are actually increasing their use of coal for power generation.

Saskatchewan has three?coal power stations, one with carbon capture utilization and storage technology, that generate 1,530 megawatts of power.China, meanwhile, has 1,118 coal?power stations that generate 1,074,000 megawatts, permitted(https://energyandcleanair.org/publication/china-permits-two-new-coal-power-plants-per-week-in-2022/) the equivalent of two new plants per week?in 2022 and authorized another 20,500 megawatts(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/trudeau-demands-climate-sacrifice-while-china-burns-coal-with-abandon) in the first quarter of 2023.India, with 73 per cent of its electricity generated by 285 coal plants, has introduced(https://cea.nic.in/wp-content/uploads/notification/2023/05/Optimal_mix_report__2029_30_Version_2.0__For_Uploading.pdf) an electrical power generation plan that is heavily dependent on increased coal power and domestic coal production.

By 2030, India plans to add another 26,900 megawatts of coal capacity and expects the country will consume 1.5 million tonnes of coal per year.Then there's Germany, a country with 63 coal power plants(https://www.statista.com/statistics/859266/number-of-coal-power-plants-by-country/) that has spent the last decade and at least 150-billion euros(https://www.dw.com/en/german-issues-in-a-nutshell-energiewende/a-38869543) promoting an "Energiewende" transition to wind and solar as it shutters emissions-free nuclear power plants but reopens coal plants.The accelerated use of coal by top global emitters will contribute far more greenhouse gasses to the atmosphere than any emissions reductions Canada could ever hope to achieve.

While Ottawa may think that it is "leading" the world into a "net-zero" future, China, India and Germany are simply not following.Premier Moe is right to challenge Ottawa's unrealistic policy expectations to achieve "net zero" emissions.
An honest, realistic national conversation about the true costs, benefits and consequences of the federal government's forced energy transition is long overdue and much needed.
It's good that Saskatchewan has chosen to open the door to a rational debate.National PostRon Wallace is an executive fellow of the Canadian Global Affairs Institute.
Tammy Nemeth is an energy analyst based in the United Kingdom.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault said it would be a criminal offence(https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/saskatchewan-running-coal-power-later-than-2030-would-be-illegal-guilbeault) if Premier Scott Moe keeps Saskatchewan's three coal power plants, which produce(https://www.saskpower.com/our-power-future/our-electricity/electrical-system/balancing-supply-options) around a quarter of the province's electricity, open past 2030.Canadians are being told by Ottawa(https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/news/2020/11/the-government-of-canada-is-leading-by-example-on-combatting-climate-change.html) and the international community(https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/unep-environment-canada-green-tech-1.3422440) that in order to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions, we must lead by example and cut our meagre 1.5 per cent share of global emissions to zero, ignoring Canadians' well-being, standards of living and energy security. Yet big emitters like China, India and Germany are not following our lead.Moving the goalposts from 2050, one part of Ottawa's net-zero plan is to implement clean electricity regulations (CER) to achieve a "net-zero" electrical grid by 2035, a plan that builds on Ottawa's 2018 coal power regulations. Those regulations specify the closure of coal power plants by 2029.Pre-empting the recently announced Canada electricity advisory council before it has even met, Guilbeault has now faced off with Premier Moe, who contends that Ottawa's unilateral decision to achieve net-zero emissions in power production by 2035 is unrealistic, even unachievable, without causing massive disruption.(https://www.theepochtimes.com/saskatchewan-premier-says-net-zero-plan-by-2035-unrealistic_5273564.html?utm_source=BN_article_paid&;src_src=BN_article_paid&;utm_campaign=breaking-2023-05-17-ca&;src_cmp=breaking-2023-05-17-ca&;utm_medium=email&;est=%5bEMAIL_SECURE_LINK%5d&;utm_term=news4&;utm_content=4C:\Users\Ron%20%20Wallace\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\INetCache\Content.Outlook\PFVLJC3D\Saskatchewan%20Premier%20Says%20Net%20Zero%20Plan%20by%202035%20%E2%80%98Unrealistic%E2%80%99%20(theepochtimes.com)Saskatchewan%20Premier%20Says%20Net%20Zero%20Plan%20by%202035%20%E2%80%98Unrealistic%E2%80%99%20(theepochtimes.com) )"We will not attempt the impossible when it comes to power production in our province," said Moe. Instead, the premier sensibly proposed to fulfill the original net-zero target by 2050.Guilbeault immediately countered(https://nationalpost.com/news/politics/saskatchewan-plan-to-run-coal-power-plants-beyond-2030-would-be-illegal-guilbeault-says) the Saskatchewan proposal with a threat: "We've regulated the ban on coal through CEPA (the Canadian Environmental Protection Act), which is a criminal tool that the federal government has ... so not complying with this regulation would be a violation of Canada's Criminal Code."Moe replied(https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/sask-moe-coal-2030-1.6848276), "When individuals in this province, or any other province, they flick their lights on or their furnace fan kicks in that's deemed illegal and cause for someone to go to jail, come get me.... We're standing up for an affordable reliable power supply here in Saskatchewan. None of those are provided by the federal net-zero plan." Indeed.The proposed federal clean electricity regulations are a "one-size-fits-all" policy in an area of clear provincial jurisdiction that is rapidly evolving into a threat to national unity. Less than eight per cent of Canada's overall emissions come from coal power, yet the CER would effectively criminalize reliable, affordable energy based on coal.Canadians are being told(https://decisions.scc-csc.ca/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/18781/index.do) that emissions and climate change are a global problem that requires global co-operation. So, are other countries following our lead by shutting coal power plants and keeping coal in the ground? The answer is a resounding "no."The world's first-, third- and seventh-largest emitters (China, India and Germany, respectively) are actually increasing their use of coal for power generation. Saskatchewan has three?coal power stations, one with carbon capture utilization and storage technology, that generate 1,530 megawatts of power.China, meanwhile, has 1,118 coal?power stations that generate 1,074,000 megawatts, permitted(https://energyandcleanair.org/publication/china-permits-two-new-coal-power-plants-per-week-in-2022/) the equivalent of two new plants per week?in 2022 and authorized another 20,500 megawatts(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/trudeau-demands-climate-sacrifice-while-china-burns-coal-with-abandon) in the first quarter of 2023.India, with 73 per cent of its electricity generated by 285 coal plants, has introduced(https://cea.nic.in/wp-content/uploads/notification/2023/05/Optimal_mix_report__2029_30_Version_2.0__For_Uploading.pdf) an electrical power generation plan that is heavily dependent on increased coal power and domestic coal production. By 2030, India plans to add another 26,900 megawatts of coal capacity and expects the country will consume 1.5 million tonnes of coal per year.Then there's Germany, a country with 63 coal power plants(https://www.statista.com/statistics/859266/number-of-coal-power-plants-by-country/) that has spent the last decade and at least 150-billion euros(https://www.dw.com/en/german-issues-in-a-nutshell-energiewende/a-38869543) promoting an "Energiewende" transition to wind and solar as it shutters emissions-free nuclear power plants but reopens coal plants.The accelerated use of coal by top global emitters will contribute far more greenhouse gasses to the atmosphere than any emissions reductions Canada could ever hope to achieve. While Ottawa may think that it is "leading" the world into a "net-zero" future, China, India and Germany are simply not following.Premier Moe is right to challenge Ottawa's unrealistic policy expectations to achieve "net zero" emissions. An honest, realistic national conversation about the true costs, benefits and consequences of the federal government's forced energy transition is long overdue and much needed. It's good that Saskatchewan has chosen to open the door to a rational debate.National PostRon Wallace is an executive fellow of the Canadian Global Affairs Institute.
